member.name: P:Neo4j.Driver.V1.Config.MaxIdleConnectionPoolSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the max idle connection pool size. If the value of this is not set, then it will default to be the same as
member.remarks: The max idle connection pool size represents the maximum number of idle connections buffered by the driver. An idle connection is a connection that has already been connected to the database instance and doesn't need to re-initialize. Setting this value to results in the idle pool size to be asigned the same value as .
Also see

member.name: P:Neo4j.Driver.V1.Config.MaxIdleSessionPoolSize
member.summary: This property is deprecated. Use instead.

member.name: P:Neo4j.Driver.V1.Config.MaxConnectionPoolSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the max connection pool size.
member.remarks: The max connection pool size specifies the allowed maximum number of idle and current in-use connections by the driver. a.k.a. ConnectionPoolSize = IdleConnectionPoolSize + InUseConnectionSize. When a driver reaches its allowed maximum connection pool size, no new connections can be established. Instead all threads that require a new connection have to wait until a connection is available to reclaim. See for the maximum waiting time to acquire an idle connection from the pool. Setting this value to will result in an infinite pool.
Also see

member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum waiting time to either acquire an idle connection from the pool when connection pool is full or create a new connection when pool is not full.

member.name: P:Neo4j.Driver.V1.Config.ConnectionIdleTimeout

member.name: P:Neo4j.Driver.V1.Config.MaxConnectionLifetime

member.name: M:Neo4j.Driver.V1.GraphDatabase.Driver(System.String)
member.summary: Returns a driver for a Neo4j instance with default configuration settings.
member.param: The URI to the Neo4j instance. Should be in the form protocol://<server location>:<port>. If port is not supplied the default of 7687 will be used. The supported protocols in URI could either be bolt or bolt+routing. The protocol bolt should be used when creating a driver connecting to the Neo4j instance directly. The protocol bolt+routing should be used when creating a driver with built-in routing.
member.returns: A new instance specified by the .
member.remarks: Ensure you provide the protocol for the .

member.name: T:Neo4j.Driver.V1.IPlan
member.summary:
This describes the Plan that the database planner produced and used (or will use) to execute your statement. This can be extremely helpful in understanding what a statement is doing, and how to optimize it. For more details, see the Neo4j Manual.
The plan for the statement is a tree of plans - each sub-tree containing zero or more child plans. The statement starts with the root plan. Each sub-plan is of a specific , which describes what that part of the plan does - for instance, perform an index lookup or filter results. The Neo4j Manual contains a reference of the available operator types, and these may differ across Neo4j versions.

member.name: P:Neo4j.Driver.V1.IPlan.OperatorType
member.summary: Gets the operation this plan is performing.

member.name: P:Neo4j.Driver.V1.IPlan.Arguments
member.summary:
Gets the arguments for the used.
Many have arguments defining their specific behavior. This map contains those arguments.

member.name: P:Neo4j.Driver.V1.IPlan.Identifiers
member.summary:
Gets a list of identifiers used by this plan.
Identifiers used by this part of the plan. These can be both identifiers introduce by you, or automatically generated identifiers.

member.name: P:Neo4j.Driver.V1.IPlan.Children
member.summary:
Gets zero or more child plans.
A plan is a tree, where each child is another plan. The children are where this part of the plan gets its input records - unless this is an that introduces new records on its own.

member.summary: This is the same as a regular - except this plan has been executed, meaning it also contains detailed information about how much work each step of the plan incurred on the database.

member.summary: Gets the number of records this part of the plan produced

member.name: P:Neo4j.Driver.V1.IProfiledPlan.Children
member.summary:
Gets zero or more child profiled plans.
A profiled plan is a tree, where each child is another profiled plan. The children are where this part of the plan gets its input records - unless this is an that introduces new records on its own.

The result summary of running a statement. The result summary interface can be used to investigate details about the result, like the type of query run, how many and which kinds of updates have been executed, and query plan and profiling information if available.
The result summary is only available after all result records have been consumed.
Keeping the result summary around does not influence the lifecycle of any associated session and/or transaction.

Unlike failures or errors, notifications do not affect the execution of a statement.

member.name: T:Neo4j.Driver.V1.ISession
member.summary:
A live session with a Neo4j instance.
Sessions serve two purposes. For one, they are an optimization. By keeping state on the database side, we can avoid re-transmitting certain metadata over and over.
Sessions also serve a role in transaction isolation and ordering semantics. Neo4j requires "sticky sessions", meaning all requests within one session must always go to the same Neo4j instance.
Session objects are not thread safe, if you want to run concurrent operations against the database, simply create multiple session objects.

member.name: M:Neo4j.Driver.V1.ISession.BeginTransaction
member.summary:
Begin a new transaction in this session. A session can have at most one transaction running at a time, if you want to run multiple concurrent transactions, you should use multiple concurrent sessions.
All data operations in Neo4j are transactional. However, for convenience we provide a method directly on this session interface as well. When you use that method, your statement automatically gets wrapped in a transaction.
If you want to run multiple statements in the same transaction, you should wrap them in a transaction using this method.
member.returns: A new transaction.

member.name: M:Neo4j.Driver.V1.ISession.BeginTransaction(System.String)
member.summary: This method is deprecated.

member.name: M:Neo4j.Driver.V1.ISession.BeginTransactionAsync
member.summary:
Asynchronously begin a new transaction in this session. A session can have at most one transaction running at a time, if you want to run multiple concurrent transactions, you should use multiple concurrent sessions.
All data operations in Neo4j are transactional. However, for convenience we provide a method directly on this session interface as well. When you use that method, your statement automatically gets wrapped in a transaction.
If you want to run multiple statements in the same transaction, you should wrap them in a transaction using this method.
member.returns: A task of a new transaction.

member.name: T:Neo4j.Driver.V1.ITransaction
member.summary:
Represents a transaction in the Neo4j database.
This interface may seem surprising in that it does not have explicit Commit or Rollback methods. It is designed to minimize the complexity of the code you need to write to use transactions in a safe way, ensuring that transactions are properly rolled back even if there is an exception while the transaction is running.

member.name: M:Neo4j.Driver.V1.ITransaction.Success
member.summary: Mark this transaction as successful. You must call this method before calling to have your transaction committed.

member.name: M:Neo4j.Driver.V1.ITransaction.Failure
member.summary:
Mark this transaction as failed. Calling will roll back the transaction.
Marking a transaction as failed is irreversable and guarantees that subsequent calls to will not change it's status.

member.name: M:Neo4j.Driver.V1.ITransaction.CommitAsync
member.summary: Asynchronously commit this transaction.

member.name: M:Neo4j.Driver.V1.ITransaction.RollbackAsync
member.summary: Asynchronously roll back this transaction.

member.name: T:Neo4j.Driver.V1.IStatementResult
member.summary: Provides access to the result as an of s. The records in the result is lazily retrived and could only be visited once.
member.remarks: Calling will enumerate the entire stream.

member.name: P:Neo4j.Driver.V1.IStatementResult.Keys
member.summary: Gets the keys in the result.

member.name: P:Neo4j.Driver.V1.IStatementResult.Summary
member.summary:
Gets the after streaming the whole records to the client. If the records in the result are not fully consumed, then calling this method will force to pull all remaining records into buffer to yield the summary.
If you want to obtain the summary but discard the records, use instead.
If all records in the records stream are already consumed, then this method will return the summary directly.

member.name: M:Neo4j.Driver.V1.IStatementResult.Peek
member.summary: Investigate the next upcoming record without changing the current position in the result.
member.returns: The next record, or null if there is no next record.

member.name: M:Neo4j.Driver.V1.IStatementResult.Consume
member.summary: Consume the entire result, yielding a summary of it. Calling this method exhausts the result.
member.returns: A summary for running the statement.
member.remarks: This method could be called multiple times. If no more record could be consumed then calling this method has the same effect of calling .

member.name: T:Neo4j.Driver.V1.IStatementResultCursor
member.summary: Provides access to the result as an asynchronous stream of s. The records in the result is lazily retrived and could only be visited once in a sequential order.
member.remarks: Calling will enumerate the entire stream.

member.name: P:Neo4j.Driver.V1.IStatementResultCursor.Keys
member.summary: Gets the keys in the result.

member.name: M:Neo4j.Driver.V1.IStatementResultCursor.SummaryAsync
member.summary:
Asynchronously gets the after streaming the whole records to the client. If the records in the result are not fully consumed, then calling this method will force to pull all remaining records into buffer to yield the summary.
If you want to obtain the summary but discard the records, use instead.
If all records in the records stream are already consumed, then this method will return the summary directly.
member.returns: A task returning the result summary of the running statement.

member.name: M:Neo4j.Driver.V1.IStatementResultCursor.PeekAsync
member.summary: Asynchronously investigates the next upcoming record without changing the current position in the result.
member.returns: A task returning next record or null if there is no next record.

member.name: M:Neo4j.Driver.V1.IStatementResultCursor.ConsumeAsync
member.summary: Asynchronously consume the entire result, yielding a summary of it. Upon completion of the returned task, the result will be exhausted.
member.returns: A task returning the summary for running the statement.
member.remarks: This method could be called multiple times. If no more record could be consumed then calling this method has the same effect of calling .
